title: Friday, 15th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:02am

PM11:05am

11:05 am

Anyway, let's move on.

PM11:06am

PM11:06am

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Well .... one amateur bomb in a bucket. Let's not throw the word "terror" around when we really mean "terrorism".

BE11:08am

Particularly when it has absolutely zero to do with the selloff.

BE11:08am

Which is entirely sterling.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Post the BOE saying yesterday, "look, this time we really mean it."

BE11:09am

As in, "some withdrawal of monetary stimulus is likely to be appropriate over the coming months."

PM11:09am

So why the belated move?

11:09 am
PM11:09am

In sterling that is

PM11:09am

Suddenly rocketed a 9 this morning

BE11:10am

Fair question. FX isn't my thing. I guess we can pin it to Gertjan Vlieghe saying, "look, seriously, we really really mean it."

11:09 am
BE11:10am

http://www.ft.com/...t-bank-of-england/

PM11:10am

http://www.bankofe...69c27c9e-111054549

BE11:10am

So, we're over $1.35 .....

11:10 am
BE11:10am

.... and the consensus is shifting quickly to a November hike.

BE11:11am

Which is where things get interesting, in terms of whether it'll be presented as a reversal of the post Brexit cut or a new cycle of tightening.

BE11:12am

(@FJP: not even you can be a solitary consensus.)

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Economists are all a bit grumbly about the mixed signals for where we are in the cycle.

BE11:13am

Natixis is readable, as always.

BE11:13am

The Bank of England (BoE) is confronted by quite an exceptional situation, as the unemployment rate is at its lowest level in more than four decades (4.3% in July) and the number in work is rising rapidly (up 181 thousand in July), whereas wage growth remains very contained (2.1% year-on-year including and excluding bonuses). At the same time, fuelled by sterling’s depreciation, inflation now nears 3% (core inflation stands at 2.7%, its highest level since 2011), which means that real earnings are declining at a fairly brisk pace (down 1.2% year-on-year according to the ONS). What will be observed is that the unemployment rate and the year-on-year change in real earnings have moved in sync since 2015 (see charts below). The erosion in real earnings, coming when the household savings rate is only 1.7% and the BoE is urging banks to tighten lending conditions, is bearing down on household consumption, which made a very modest 0.1pp contribution towards Q2 GDP growth.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BE11:14am

As regards the outlook, the BoE faces another conundrum. On the one hand, business investment and recruitment intentions, without being exceptional, are not that poor. On the other hand, as observed by the BoE in its monetary policy summary published yesterday, Brexit-related uncertainties are considerable.

BE11:15am

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Still according to the monetary policy summary, there are factors in favour of tightening monetary policy in a not distant future, notably on the view that evidence continues to accumulate of what is now a fairly limited degree of spare capacity (production capacity utilisation rate stands at 82.5%, while the employment rate for persons aged between 16 and 64 reaches 75.3%). There are also factors that could prompt the central bank to proceed gingerly, notably consumption and investment that remain weak, while household confidence is moderate.

BE11:16am

So, start of day the likelihood of a November hike was through 50% according to OIS.

BE11:17am

So ...................... not quite nailed on. Back to Natixis.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

In particular, there will need to be confirmation of the rebound in consumption anticipated by the BoE. However, a tightening of monetary policy at this stage is not without risk. The main risks are well known:
 Household debt is mainly at variable interest rates, so households are directly impacted by any rise in the bank rate. Ideally, an eventual rise in interest rates would need to be offset by an acceleration in wage growth, which is not certain to happen. Or, sterling’s appreciation would have to lead to weaker inflation and hence, all other things being equal, to a rise in real earnings year-on-year.

BE11:17am

 Sterling could strengthen if its remuneration is more attractive, which would be bad news for British exporters, unless of course global growth picks up strongly at the same time (the lesser competiveness of British exports being offset by stronger global demand). Sterling has in fact picked up against the euro and US dollar since the end of August.
 A tightening of monetary conditions (rise in interest rates, appreciation of sterling) some 15 months before Brexit, when the first phase of the negotiations has not been wrapped up and is likely to drag on (it is not even certain the EU27 and UK can reach an agreement on the three issues, i.e. Brexit bill, status of expatriates, and Irish border), is a further source of uncertainty, which could rapidly depress consumer confidence and business sentiment.

BE11:18am

(@Penny: thanks, didn't have time to check before 11.)

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And ........... in the dovish camp, Morgan Stanley ............

BE11:19am

The condition for tightening is "continued erosion of slack". We think this means that employment and unemployment data will be more important to watch than pay growth. In particular, despite the focus on underlying inflationary pressure in the minutes, when it came to wage growth, although the MPC noted that it saw "some signs of recovery" in underlying pay growth, the majority still said there was not yet evidence of a sustained pick-up, but that was not enough to prevent more hawkish policy guidance. However, employment growth featured heavily in its assessment of diminishing spare capacity – both as a support for consumer demand and as an indicator of weak productivity, and therefore potential supply, growth. This makes the August employment data out on October 18 a particular focus.

BE11:19am

Just on hold: If employment growth continues at the current robust rate (0.6%Q, +181k), and is accompanied by 3Q growth above the BoE staff projection of 0.3%Q, then we would now expect the MPC to hike at the November 2 Inflation Report meeting. But at the moment, we forecast a deceleration in employment growth as a lagged effect of this year's slowdown in growth, which we think should be enough to keep the MPC on hold. We also expect speeches and TSC hearings from MPC members – in particular Haldane and Carney, who have both shifted in a more dovish direction recently, and the new members Ramsden and Tenreyro – to firm up our assessment of MPC intentions.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

.......... all of which is rather inconvenient for my mortgage deal, which expires at the end of the month. I'm spending several hours per day trying to compare the yield curve to fixed versus tracker plus hedging off fee rates. Still don't quite understand why the mortgage system is designed with so many beartraps.

BE11:21am

Anyway, is that enough BOE?

PM11:21am

Sure, enough -- but interesting

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Pivotal moment maybe

BE11:22am

......... or just a reversal of of the Brexit emergency cut. Or crying wolf again. Very hard to say.

BE11:23am

11:25 am

PM11:26am

Market structure -- the lack of it

11:26 am
PM11:26am

PM11:26am

We're not fans of Fever Tree either !

BE11:26am

11:27 am
BE11:27am

I'd suggest that punter stocks tend to go down sharp in selloffs, and Fever Tree's the definition of a punter stock with an extra inheritance tax avoidance kicker.

PM11:27am

Yeah, i know

BE11:27am

Though I'm equally happy to blame the machines.

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:28am

So, to fallers. Which is everything.

BE11:28am

Leading us down is Carnival, which we can blame on the dollar and so forth ......

11:28 am
BE11:28am

........ but also a Credit Suisse downgrade.

BE11:29am

Familiar themes. Too many boats, too few pensioners to put on them.

BE11:29am

Industry supply growth is significant (2017-22E CAGR 6.1%) and when coupled with increasing demand threats for 2018E in the top 3 cruise markets (Caribbean, Mediterranean and China) we assume more cautious 2018E yield growth (1.5% from 3.0%). 2018E EPS and our DCF based target price fall 10%, we downgrade our rating to Neutral.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Capacity growth a greater concern given demand risks: Our updated Credit Suisse cruise model indicates 2017-22E capacity growth of 6.1%. Whilst this is little changed and similar to history (2000-17E 5.7%), the absolute level of capacity growth in 2018-21E is double the last 5 years. We had been comfortable with that supply growth given strong near term demand trends (with bookings at record levels) and structural opportunities for growth in EM. However, we highlight increasing demand threats for 2018E from the top 3 cruise markets. 1) Caribbean (39% of global pax) post Hurricane Irma with 24% of the region potentially severely damaged (measured by pax volume) plus 2005 a proxy when EPS downgrades were 10%; 2) Mediterranean (14% of pax) post the Barcelona terror attacks given it is the #1 cruise port in the region and the 60% decline in Eastern Med volumes seen since 2011 (i.e. Athens/Turkey) and 3) China (12% of pax) with the Korea travel ban still in place and the industry planning to trim capacity by 5% in 2018E. We cut 2018E yield growth to 1.5% (from 3.0%) and EPS by 10% (7% due to yield and 3% due to higher fuel price).

BE11:30am

We have Carnival results coming towards the end of the month, which will be fine.

BE11:31am

There's some fascinating stuff around hurricanes and when customers need refunds based on port days. Something to do with Wednesday, as I remember, and the two recent biggies were quite convenient for the industry.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

CS's concerns are rather more long term.

BE11:32am

Target price falls to $70 or 5300p: We maintain a DCF based approach to valuing Carnival and given the 10% EPS fall our DCF moves from $78 to $70, broadly in line with the current price and hence we downgrade to Neutral from Outperform. The 2018E PE of 16.2x is just below a through cycle average of 16.4x (1997 to 2017 avg).

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:36am

Here's the link you couldn't post earlier: https://www.invest...ed-to-be-like-this

PM11:36am

Since August 24 we've gone from 1.28 to here

11:36 am
BE11:37am

We've a proper selloff developing, which is exclusively UK and rather underlines how much what we do each day is driven by sterling.

BE11:37am

Oh, that reminds me.

BE11:38am

Something though from John Lonski, Chief Economist, Moody’s Capital Markets Research.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

What Might Trigger the Next Market Plunge?

BE11:38am

Rates, basically.

BE11:38am

An overvalued equity market and an extraordinarily low VIX index offer no assurance of impending doom for US equities. Provided that interest rates do not rocket higher, expectations of corporate earnings growth should be sufficient for the purpose of avoiding a severe equity market correction that would doubtless include the return of corporate bond yield spreads in excess of 700 bp for high-yield and above 200 bp for Baa-rated issues.
For now, the good news is that early September’s Blue Chip consensus expects core profits, or pretax profits from current production, to grow by 4.4% in 2017 and by 4.5% in 2018. Moreover, earnings-sensitive securities should be able to shoulder the 2.5% 10-year Treasury yield projected for 2017’s final quarter. However, the realization of a projected Q4-2018 average of 3.0% for the 10-year Treasury yield could materially reduce US share prices.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Then we get some history about previous drops and their depths.

BE11:39am

Which is always a flawed experiment as the range is far too wide to reach a proper conclusion.

BE11:40am

The detail says the last two recessions halved share prices. But should we expect a third one like that?

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Moody's says no. Nevertheless, mind how you go.

BE11:41am

The equity market’s five other episodes of at least a -10% drop from the relevant record high followed peaks that were established in May 2015, October 2007, March 2000, June 1998, and June 1990. Two of the deep declines did not occur in the context of a recession, namely the most recent correction of 2015-2016 and the brief, but severe, setback of 1998’s second half. Compared to their previous highs, the market value of common stock sank by -12.9% before bottoming in February 2016 and fell by -13.7% before bottoming in September 1998. In addition, 15 months passed before the equity market set a new record high in August 2016, while it took only five months for equities to establish a new high in December 1998.

BE11:41am

Far more severe was the -50.6% cumulative plunge by the market value of US common stock from an October 2007 high to a March 2009 trough. Not until January 2013 did the market surpass its top of October 2007.
Even longer than the 63-month wait for the market’s full recovery from its post-October 2007 drubbing was the 81-month long hiatus before the market returned to its high of March 2000. After topping off in March 2000, equities would trend lower by a cumulative -42.8% until bottoming in October 2002. But, not until December 2006 did the market set a new high.
Finally, a recession overlapped a -16.6% cumulative slide by the market value of common stock from June 1990’s peak to September 1990’s bottom. Unlike the next two recession-related sell-offs, equities recovered sharply and, by March 1991, the market surpassed its June 1990 high. In conclusion, the rich valuation of today’s US equity market very much warns of at least a -10% drop in the market value of US common stock in response to either unexpectedly high interest rates or a contraction of profits. Perhaps, the prudent investor should be braced for at least a -20% plunge in the value of a well-diversified portfolio at some point during the next 18 months.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Kinda retaily, that. But it passes the time in a selloff.

undefined
BE11:42am

Abcam mentioned some time ago.

11:42 am
Abcam PLC (ABC:LSE): Last: 1,027, down 45 (-4.20%), High: 1,062, Low: 985.00, Volume: 486.96k
BE11:43am

Been lower. Lots lower. Which seems to have been a sector meltdown rather than anything Abcam specific.

BE11:44am

On two bits of news to note from elsewhere: Bavarian Nordic's scrapped its cancer thing (shares down 50%) and Santhera has had a regulatory knockback for its eye thing (shares also down 50%).

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Other than that, there are a few forecast downgrades ticking through for Abcam post results.

BE11:44am

JP Morgan, for instance.

BE11:45am

(Results were .... 11th, was it?)

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We hosted an investor lunch with Abcam following the FY results and came away positive about the opportunity mid-long term. Taking a step back, this is a stock with HSD underlying growth and 30%+ margin which clearly demands a premium valuation. The question is how much of a premium? The LT potential from the non-research opportunity could clearly tip the scale, however visibility is likely to remain low in the near term and in our view this should be viewed as a free option. Our price target is 14% below the current share price, but 2/3 of this is set on 2018 multiples which arguably don’t capture the non-research option value – which is currently impossible to quantify, but clearly carries some value. We remain Neutral.

BE11:46am

Abcam saw RabMAb growth of 25% in FY17, and is targeting recombinant antibody (primarily RabMAb) growth of 20-25% in FY18E. Management also sees more opportunities with immunoassays and is targeting 20-25% growth in FY18E. While the Customs business (Abcam Inside) provides the story LT optionality, the company is at least a year away from guiding investors about the scale and growth profile of this business.

BE11:47am

Skipping the bit about gross margins ticking higher rather slowly, as in over the next five years, on transition to higher margin products.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Also skipping the bit about chucking more money into ERP.

BE11:47am

As in £44-46m, from £35-£37m previously.

BE11:48am

What it does for forecasts is:

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Our earnings revisions result in 9-11% downgrades on an adjusted basis, primarily due to a lower Adjusted EBIT margin guidance by management and FX. Reported numbers see a 16% downgrade in FY18E due to the higher ERP costs. We revise our Price Target from 864p to 946p as we have reviewed the multiples relative to the sector given the quality of the business and premium growth profile.

BE11:48am

So there you go. Hope that helps.

undefined
11:48 am
PM11:49am

We could mention one or two positive things, if we can them

PM11:49am

Next!

PM11:49am

Top of the leader board

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Simon Irwin at Credit Suisse won't like this

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 5,043, up 48.5 (+0.97%), High: 5,115, Low: 5,010, Volume: 500.17k
PM11:50am

He's grudgingly upped his target price from 40 quid to £42

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But sticking with his underperform advice

PM11:50am

While 1H profits (PBT -9.5% Y/Y) were weak, they were bolstered by credit, Label and International and the deterioration of the underlying Next brand in the UK appears to be accelerating. Given disclosure, the 1H components are not that clear, but assuming better trading in 2H, we still assume that Next Brand UK sales will be -4% in 17/18E and EBIT -15%. This all comes before there is any meaningful decline in credit, which we continue to believe is over-earning and likely to see margin pressure from efforts to stabilise credit account numbers.

PM11:50am

Is that fair? -- that the actual quality of the brand is falling away?

11:50 am
PM11:50am

maybe

PM11:51am

Label and Directory Overseas (15% of FY EBIT) have continued to grow faster than we expected, but as 1H showed, not fast enough to offset the decline even with favourable FX, and it is hard to see this accelerate in subsequent years.■ Accelerating store de-leveraging, NextUnlimited, Label, Overseas Directory and declining credit participation all point to a lower margin future from an industry-high level, and in a fragmenting apparel market it's hard to see how Next can offset this with higher sales growth. As a result, we continue to expect multi-year earnings declines.■ 3Q has clearly started well (better weather and improved execution) and we are increasing current year EPS by 3.7% due to c1% higher sales, lower corporate tax rates and central costs. However this still leaves EPS -7.7% Y/Y and we forecast similar declines in future years, resulting in lower special dividends in future years as cash conversion declines

undefined
11:51 am
PM11:51am

The other obvious positive mover is Wetherspoon

PM11:51am

But i really can't face discussing taht

PM11:52am

read the figs yourself

11:51 am
PM11:52am

https://www.invest...1709150700038252Q/

BE11:52am

We've done the argument on here a few times that it's the only one in the sector that has room to raise prices.

BE11:53am

Today's figures do seem to back that up. LFL up 6.1%, strong current trading, outlook maintained.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Is there much readthrough for the sector? Not really.

BE11:54am

Because Wetherspoons has its niche and those who've tried to get into it -- Greene King's Fayre and Square is the obvious example -- have tended to fail. Here's Barclays.

BE11:54am

Strong FY17 results. EBIT +17% to £128.5m vs Barclays £125m, Bloomberg consensus £125m. PBT +27% to £102.8m vs Barclays £92.8m, consensus £96m. EPS +43% to 69.2p vs Barclays 60.4p and consensus 63.2p. FCF per share is also strong at 97p, a record level. We believe that some consensus forecasts may have been made on the basis of the 53 week financial year vs Barclays 52 week forecasts. EBIT margin was 7.74% towards the higher end of the guided range of 7.6-7.8% in the pre close statement. Within the detail, Repairs and Maintenance increased sharply to £66m, 4% of sales vs £54.9m in FY 16, 3.4% of sales, so this is not a strong margin performance that is based on falling repairs spending. Since the year end, trading in FY18 so far (July year end) has been strong, and LFLs are +6.1% vs comps for the equivalent period of 4.1%. The company comments: “This is a positive start, but is for a few weeks only – and is very unlikely to continue for the rest of the year”. The company continues to state that they need LFLs of 3-4% to match FY17 PBT. The company “anticipate a trading outcome for the current financial year in line with our expectations”, albeit without referencing these exact expectations. Barclays’ forecasts are currently for LFLs of 2% with margins of 7.6% which drives PBT of £91m vs Bloomberg consensus £92m. We remain Overweight on Wetherspoon in the pub sector, with market share gains from its value for money proposition very clear with possible gains to both sales and margin from the Order and Pay App. The trading performance contrasts sharply with the rest of the sector, with Coffer Peach data illustrating a fall of 0.3% for pubs in August and the wider sector +0.2% including restaurants. Valuation: Dec-18 PE 17.3x, EV/EBITDA 9.5x, FCF yield 8% on our current forecasts.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

And for a seller, Morgan Stanley.

BE11:55am

We assume LfL sales growth of 3.5%, total sales growth of
0.3% and an EBIT margin of 7.7% in FY18. We forecast EBIT of £128m (flat), EPS of 66.5 and FCF per share of 86p, compared to consensus at £124m, 62p, and 72.3p, respectively. We expect to raise forecasts marginally given the slightly stronger FY17 results and excellent start to trading, which contrasts strongly with Greene King's weak recent results. JD Wetherspoon’s value proposition could be a relative benefit in a downturn. Nevertheless, competition from casual dining and coffee shops remains high, the pub disposal programme means total growth will remain much lower than historical levels (9% average 2011-15, we forecast 2-4% in 2017-20) and net debt remains high. We see risk/reward skewed to the downside and continue to rate the shares Underweight.

BE11:56am

And for a buyer, Investec.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Reiterate our Buy recommendation: JD Wetherspoon continues to outperform the UK pub sector – we believe benefitting from its value offering and well invested pub estate. Whilst the UK consumer backdrop remains unfavourable, in our view JD Wetherspoon is potentially benefitting from trading down within the sector and, as a result, taking market share. With potential for further upgrades, we reiterate our Buy recommendation and increase our TP to 1170p.

BE11:56am

That seems to cover the field.

undefined
11:57 am
BE11:57am

(@Penny: that was Berenberg: https://www.ft.com...-94e2-c5b903247afd )

BE11:58am

Quite a headline over at the Telegraph.

BE11:58am

JD Sports shrugs off nuclear fears to strike South Korean deal

11:58 am
BE11:58am

http://www.telegra...south-korean-deal/

BE11:59am

£5.5m investment in something called Hot-T.

BE11:59am

But I guess you don't get to write about nuclear war much if you're a retail correspondent.

11:59 am
JD Sports Fashion PLC (JD.:LSE): Last: 379.80, up 7.7 (+2.07%), High: 380.50, Low: 370.40, Volume: 922.32k
BE12:01pm

Peel Hunt likes it.

BE12:01pm

JD is continuing its acquisitive strategy by entering into a JV
with Shoemarker in South Korea. It will rebrand 23 profitable
stores that currently trade under the Hot-T fascia to JD. It is not
a major surprise that South Korea has become the latest country
to attract JD's interest and we have no doubt that this will all be
done with the big brands' backing. The deal's multiple seems
unstretching (c10x EBITDA) given it is likely that JD will
galvanise the stores' profitability, and as another part of the
global portfolio it makes perfect sense. We wouldn't rule out
further moves from JD in Asia and, maybe ultimately, to the US.
The multiple doesn't reflect the opportunity to become one of a
handful of truly global sports retailers, and the scale that may
bring. Buy.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Anyway, interesting move. Good luck to them.

Ok, thanks for all that Bryce

12:01 pm
PM12:02pm

PM12:02pm
